questions.text: A patient of supracondylar humerus fracture is unable to flex interphalangeal joint of the thumb. No sensory deficit was found. Which nerve is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Anterior interosseous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In case of supracondylar humerus fracture, presenting with an inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb, without any sensory deficit, the nerve most commonly injured is the anterior interosseous nerve, a terminal branch of the median nerve.

questions.text: Fracture at which site in leg will cause failure of dorsiflexion of foot? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Proximal fibular neck

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Injury to the proximal neck of fibula causes paralysis of dorsiflexion of the foot because around this portion, the common peroneal nerve winds, which supplies the dorsiflexors of the foot.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl arrives with several swellings and numerous brown rashes. Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Additionally, she has a past medical record of hypothyroidism. The provided image displays an X-ray of her femur. What is the probable diagnosis from the options provided?(INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. McCune-Albright syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots . Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas. There are irregularities in her biochemical values. Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome .
  • ➤ The presentation of several swellings and numerous brown rashes represents café Au lait spots .
  • ➤ café Au lait spots
  • ➤ Bone scans reveal heightened activity in the femur, skull, and rib areas.
  • ➤ There are irregularities in her biochemical values.
  • ➤ Presence of past medical history of hypothyroidism, and Shepherd crook deformity of femur in the given image, all point towards the McCune Albright Syndrome .
  • ➤ McCune Albright Syndrome

questions.text: Which is the most common Osteoporotic fracture site? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vertebral fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.
  • ➤ The most common site for osteoporotic fractures is the vertebral column followed by femur (mainly neck) and lower end of the radius.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations are not used for diagnosing osteoporosis?(INICET NOV 2020) DEXA Bone scan Quantitative CT Chemical analysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DEXA scan is the investigation of choice. Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations. DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.
  • ➤ DEXA scan is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ Quantitative CT is a bone mineral density (BMD) measurement technique in which the CT scanner is calibrated using solid phantoms (made of calcium hydroxyapatite, representing various bone mineral densities) placed under the patient in a pad. With this calibration, the Hounsfield units are converted to bone mineral density values. The technique can be used for both peripheral and central BMD measurements, with lumbar spine and hip being preferred locations.
  • ➤ DEXA measures the bone mineral density of both the outer (cortical) shell and the inner (trabecular) structure of the bone. QCT, on the other hand, measures only the inner part. Because of this difference, QCT studies of the spine show a lower T-score than a DEXA would.

questions.text: Patient had a fall on Outstretched hand. He presented with Fracture and displacement of Base of 1st metacarpal. This fracture is known as: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bennet’s fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.
  • ➤ A Bennett's fracture involves the base of the first metacarpal with displacement due to muscle pull, often resulting from a fall on an outstretched hand.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the following image. (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Type II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the Type II Salter-Harris physeal injury in children. A Type II Salter-Harris fracture involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis and is the most common type of growth plate fracture.
  • ➤ The given image shows the Type II Salter-Harris physeal injury in children.
  • ➤ A Type II Salter-Harris fracture involves both the growth plate and a part of the metaphysis and is the most common type of growth plate fracture.

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient’s hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?(AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: C
options.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints

options.label: D
options.text: Post-traumatic dystrophy with complex regional pain syndrome

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Rheumatoid arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image and the symptoms in a female of pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand, morning stiffness with problem in squatting is clinical for Rheumatoid Arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of Klumpke’s palsy? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Claw hand

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic deformity of Klumpke’s palsy is Claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles and weakness of wrist and finger flexors.
  • ➤ The characteristic deformity of Klumpke’s palsy is Claw hand due to paralysis of intrinsic hand muscles and weakness of wrist and finger flexors.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe back ache and the following x-ray after an RTA. Diagnose the fracture present. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Chance fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A Chance fracture is a flexion-distraction injury that extends through all three columns of the spine and is commonly seen in patients who experience a sudden forward motion, such as in a seatbelt-related injury during a car accident.

questions.text: A post-menopausal woman with previous history of Colle’s fracture is complaining of backache. Which of the following statement is false? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Teriparatide should be given before supplementing bisphosphonates one at a time.

options.label: B
options.text: Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day.

options.label: D
options.text: Oral Vitamin D3 given along with oral calcium.

questions.correct_answer: B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than one year.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year. But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.
  • ➤ In post-menopausal osteoporotic females, bisphosphonates can be given for more than a year.
  • ➤ But their prolonged use is associated with risk of hip fractures, so it should be assessed with x-rays with time.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents with lesion in tibial diaphysis. Histopathological examination is shown in below given image. On IHC, it was MIC-2 positive and synaptophysin positive cells. Most likely diagnosis will be: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Ewing sarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.
  • ➤ The combination of the patient's age, the diaphyseal location of the bone lesion, the classic small round blue cell morphology on histology, and especially the strong MIC-2 (CD99) positivity with some synaptophysin positivity, makes Ewing sarcoma the definitive and most appropriate diagnosis.

questions.text: Match the following:(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A-3, B-4, C-5, D-1

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A. Madelung deformity involves distal radius. It is the volar translation of the wrist. It is seen associated with Turner Syndrome.
  • • A. Madelung deformity
  • • B. Haglund deformity is the bony prominence over calcaneum and the overlying retrocalcaneal bursitis.
  • • B. Haglund deformity
  • • C. Buttonhole deformity is the abnormal extension at distal interphalangeal joint and flexion at proximal interphalangeal joint and is seen with Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • C. Buttonhole deformity
  • • D. Gunstock deformity is seen in Cubitus varus. It is a complication frequently seen after untreated supracondylar fracture of humerus.
  • • D. Gunstock deformity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: About giant-cell tumor, all are true except:(AIIMS MAY 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Commonly presents in the 20-40 years age group

options.label: B
options.text: Matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells

options.label: C
options.text: Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

options.label: D
options.text: It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis

questions.correct_answer: C. Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Osteoclast giant cells constitute the proliferative component of the tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant cell tumors commonly presents in the 20-40 years of age group. Microscopically, the matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells. Osteoclast giant cells induce the proliferation of the monoculcear macrophage cells, increasing the mononuclear cell population. It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis in about 4% cases.
  • ➤ Giant cell tumors commonly presents in the 20-40 years of age group.
  • ➤ Microscopically, the matrix consists of proliferating mononuclear cells.
  • ➤ Osteoclast giant cells induce the proliferation of the monoculcear macrophage cells, increasing the mononuclear cell population.
  • ➤ It is a benign tumor which may have lung metastasis in about 4% cases.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of fall on an outstretched hand presented in OPD with complaints of pain and swelling in the right wrist. On examination, you observe a dinner fork deformity can be noticed. What is the correct statement regarding this patient? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Proximal and Lateral displacement of radius

options.label: B
options.text: Proximal and dorsal displacement of radius

options.label: C
options.text: Proximal and Lateral displacement of ulna

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The dinner fork deformity is commonly seen in the colle’s fracture, which is the proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius after a fall on the outstretched hand. It is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females.
  • ➤ The dinner fork deformity is commonly seen in the colle’s fracture, which is the proximal and dorsal displacement of the radius after a fall on the outstretched hand. It is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females.

questions.text: A 6-month-old baby was brought to OPD with the following presentation. How will you manage the patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Manipulation and cast

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with CTEV of age group less than 1 year, the mainstay treatment done is manipulation and cast in the order of correction of cavus – adduction – varus – equinus (C-AV-E). The fulcrum while manipulation lies at the head of talus. The duration of this treatment method is for 6-8 weeks.
  • ➤ In children with CTEV of age group less than 1 year, the mainstay treatment done is manipulation and cast in the order of correction of cavus – adduction – varus – equinus (C-AV-E).

  • ➤ The duration of this treatment method is for 6-8 weeks.

questions.text: Which HLA is associated with Reiter’s syndrome? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) HLA B27

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) and other spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis. Approximately 75-80% of patients with reactive arthritis test positive for HLA-B27. But it should not be used as a diagnostic tool for acute ReA.
  • ➤ HLA-B27 is strongly associated with reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome) and other spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, and enteropathic arthritis.

  • ➤ But it should not be used as a diagnostic tool for acute ReA.

questions.text: A patient came to be emergency department with a radiograph showing posterior dislocation of hip. No associated fractures are seen. What is the next step in management?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

  • ➤ The treatment of choice for posterior dislocations of hip is closed reduction/manipulation under general anesthesia in cases with no associated fractures.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG 2019)

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented in OPD with complaints of a gradual progressive swelling around his wrist for 2 months as shown below. A radiograph was taken. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Osteoclastoma

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor typically appears in patient of 20-40 years of age. They are most commonly seen at the epiphyseal region of the long bone and also about the subchondral bone. Radiologically, the lesions are eccentrically located, purely lytic, expands/breaks through the cortex.
  • ➤ Osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor typically appears in patient of 20-40 years of age. They are most commonly seen at the epiphyseal region of the long bone and also about the subchondral bone. Radiologically, the lesions are eccentrically located, purely lytic, expands/breaks through the cortex.

questions.text: A young man had a fall on his outstretched hand, presented to the hospital with pain on the radial side of wrist and swelling in the anatomical snuff box. X-ray showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Scaphoid fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ The given x-ray, mechanism of injury, and presenting complaints of the patient points towards the diagnosis of scaphoid fracture.

questions.text: True statements about fracture shaft of femur: (AIIMS MAY 2019) More commonly in elderly. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly. Associated with pulmonary complications. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. c & d are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years. It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly. It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.
  • ➤ Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years.
  • ➤ It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly.
  • ➤ It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • ➤ Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Cauda equina syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.

questions.text: Assertion: Distal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. Reason: Blood supply is retrograde from its distal to proximal end.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reasoning are independently true/correct and Reason is not the correct explanation of the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis. This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid is retrograde, from its distal end to its proximal end. At the proximal end, the blood supply diminishes. This accounts for increased chances of avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment when the proximal pole of the scaphoid is fractured. Thus, in the given question, assertion is an incorrect statement while the reason is a correct statement.
  • ➤ The proximal pole of scaphoid is the most common bone to undergo avascular necrosis.
  • ➤ This is because the blood supply to the scaphoid is retrograde, from its distal end to its proximal end.
  • ➤ At the proximal end, the blood supply diminishes.
  • ➤ This accounts for increased chances of avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment when the proximal pole of the scaphoid is fractured.
  • ➤ Thus, in the given question, assertion is an incorrect statement while the reason is a correct statement.

questions.text: A patient who used to workout regularly at the gym, gradually developed pain in the hip which is aggravated while squatting. He gives history of regular steroid and creatine use over last six months. There is flattening of femoral head and subchondral cysts were seen on X-ray. What is the likely diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) AVN of hip

  • ➤ Regular steroid is the major risk factor for development of avascular necrosis of the hip. Flattening of femoral head on radiograph is also seen in the avascular necrosis of hip.

questions.text: Match the Eponym with their fractures.(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-e

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 1. Pilon’s fracture: It is the intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal tibia. It is also known as Plafond fracture, Tibia Plafond fracture, Distal Tibial Explosion fracture. The high energy axial compression force if the tibia acts as a pestle, driving vertically into the talus.
  • ➤ 1. Pilon’s fracture:
  • ➤ 2. Runner’s fracture: It is the fracture of lower end of the fibula. They are usually the stress fracture, commonly seen in runners.
  • ➤ Runner’s fracture:
  • ➤ 3. Cotton’s fracture: It is the trimalleolar fracture in the ankle i.e., there is involvement of medial and lateral malleoli, and posterior aspect of the tibial plafond (also called as posterior malleolus). This is a more unstable fracture and may be associated with ligamentous injury.
  • ➤ Cotton’s fracture:
  • ➤ 4. Chauffer’s fracture: It is an intra-articular oblique fracture of the styloid process of the radius. It is sustained from a direct trauma like a blow to the back of the wrist or from forced dorsiflexion and abduction of the wrist.
  • ➤ 4. Chauffer’s fracture:

questions.text: Salter Harris Type 1 injury passes through which zone? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertrophic zone

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypertrophic zone of the physis has a high bone turnover. It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur. Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

  • ➤ It is the area where all Salter-Harris injuries occur.
  • ➤ Thus, the Type I injuries occurs in the hypertrophic zone of the physis.

questions.text: Which of the following childhood injuries will lead to a fish tail injury? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Distal humerus in children

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fish tail deformity is a rare complication of distal humerus fracture in children.

questions.text: Tom-Smith arthritis destroys: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Femoral capital epiphysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tom smith arthritis or the septic arthritis in children, most commonly affects the femoral capital epiphysis.

questions.text: Given the radiograph of a 13-year-old child who presented with fall on elbow. Which of the following bone is fractured? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Humerus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.
  • ➤ The image given in the question shows the fracture of upper end or proximal end of humerus.

questions.text: An adolescent fell on an outstretched hand. For management, the doctor ties a cast as shown in the given image. Which fracture did the patient suffer from? (FMGE 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Scaphoid fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For the treatment of undisplaced and stable scaphoid fractures, a glass-holding cast is applied.

questions.text: Shown in image is an orthopedic procedure being performed. Identity the procedure? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.correct_answer: A. Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intraosseous cannulation for fluid therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.
  • ➤ Intraosseous access for fluid therapy is an orthopedic procedure done in pediatric patients to provide fluid therapy.

questions.text: A young man, aged 25, arrived with complaints of being unable to bend the distal interphalangeal joint of his 4th and 5th fingers. Additionally, he faced difficulty in gripping a piece of paper between his fingers. Where is the probable location of the injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The marked structure C is the medial epicondyle. The Ulnar nerve passes from behind the epicondyle. Injury to the ulnar nerve at this area causes ulnar claw hand i.e., the extension of IP joints of 4 th and 5 th fingers; along with weakness in grip of the hand.

questions.text: A 75-year-old female presents to emergency department with pain in right hip and is unable to walk. She gives a history of fall in bathroom. On examination, you observe that there is shortening of left lower limb and is externally rotated. There is no history of arthritis. X-ray of hip is given below. What will be the management? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hemiarthroplasty

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In an elderly patient with neck of femur fracture, hemiarthroplasty is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.
  • ➤ Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center. He has a severe pain in his left hip and, on examination the hip is exquisitely tender with restricted range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformity is seen in the patient? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of hip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.
  • ➤ Restricted hip range of motion with FABER deformity of the hip is suggestive of anterior dislocation of the hip.

questions.text: A child presents with fever and discharging pus from right leg for 3 months. Following is the radiograph of the child. Identify the labelled structured:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Involucrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum . It has some holes to drain out pus, called as cloaca . Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.
  • ➤ The given image shows the dense sclerotic bone called the involucrum . It has some holes to drain out pus, called as cloaca .
  • ➤ involucrum
  • ➤ cloaca
  • ➤ Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. This appears denser than the normal bone because there is no decalcification like the normal bone.
  • ➤ Sequestrum

questions.text: What is the diagnosis?(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giant cell tumor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given image shows a Giant Cell Tumor of the distal end of radius.

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly defines Galeazzi fracture-dislocation?(AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

options.label: B
options.text: Ulnar fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

options.label: C
options.text: Ulnar shaft fracture and disruption of superior radio-ulnar joint

options.label: D
options.text: Radial collateral ligament tear with interosseous membrane tear and radial shaft fracture

questions.correct_answer: A. Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Radial fracture with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and lower radio-ulnar joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.
  • ➤ Galeazzi fracture is the fracture of the distal 1/3rd shaft of the radius with disruption of triangular fibrocartilage complex and distal radioulnar joint.

questions.text: A young patient with RTA sustained an open fracture of femur which was operated and stabilized as shown below. Identify the fixator.(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rail fixator

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fixator shown in the image in the question is a Rail Fixator, used to treat open fractures to fill the bone gap.

questions.text: Which muscle is inserted on the lesser trochanter of the femur? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Psoas major

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Psoas Major muscle inserts at the lesser trochanter of the femur and is involved in flexing the hip joint.
  • ➤ The Psoas Major muscle inserts at the lesser trochanter of the femur and is involved in flexing the hip joint.

questions.text: Painful arc syndrome is seen in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mid-abduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Painful arc syndrome, a clinical manifestation of impingement syndrome, is observed during mid-range shoulder abduction, typically between 60° and 120°. This condition is often seen in individuals engaging in activities that involve repeated arm elevation, and management may include NSAIDs, corticosteroid injections, physical therapy, or, in refractory cases, surgical intervention to decompress the subacromial space.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone. Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.
  • ➤ The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • ➤ Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.

questions.text: Fallen fragment sign is characteristic of:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Simple bone cyst

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fallen fragment sign is seen in simple (unicameral) bone cyst. It is a thinned cortical fragment that fractures and falls into the base of the lesion, confirming its empty cystic nature

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman comes with a history of Colles’ fracture 6 months ago. Her DEXA scan reveals T score of -2.5. What is the next best step?(INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alendronate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alendronate, a drug of class of bisphosphonates is the drug of choice for the treatment of osteoporosis.

questions.text: Identify the structure pointed in the anatomical snuffbox. (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Extensor pollicis longus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The marked muscle tendon the given image is of the extensor pollicis longus in the anatomical snuffbox. It forms the medial boundary of the snuffbox and functions to extend the thumb.
  • ➤ The marked muscle tendon the given image is of the extensor pollicis longus in the anatomical snuffbox.
  • ➤ It forms the medial boundary of the snuffbox and functions to extend the thumb.

questions.text: Which statement is incorrect about the pathology shown?(NEET PG 2019)

options.label: D
options.text: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

questions.correct_answer: D. Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of bone typically manifests as an eccentric lytic lesion in the epiphyseal region of long bones with distinct margins. The mainstay of treatment for GCT is surgical intervention, either through curettage or excision followed by bone grafting, rather than chemotherapy. This surgical approach helps ensure complete removal of the tumor and helps prevent recurrence.
